<!-- # Geospatial analysis: read external data -->

## Introduction

Let say that you receive a raw `data.frame` with coordinate points per row, and I want to create a Thematic map with it, how can I make it using `{ggplot2}`? Or that you use a package to get spatial data but in a object class like `SpatVector` or `SpatialPolygonsDataFrame`, how can I use them with `{ggplot2}`?

![Figure 1. (A) Map from a raw data.frame with coordinate points. (B) Dot map with the same data converted to a `sf` object.](images/geoboundaries_05.png)

We need `sf` class objects to create `ggplot` maps! So, today we are going to learn how to **convert foreign** spatial objects to `sf`, either polygon or point data, to keep making `ggplot2` maps!

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

## Learning objectives

1.  Convert **foreign** objects to **`sf` class** using the `st_as_sf()` function from the `{sf}` package.

2.  Convert foreign **polygon** data in `SpatVector` class to `sf`.

3.  Convert foreign **point** data in `data.frame` class to `sf`.

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

### Convert foreign Polygon geometries to `sf` {.unnumbered}

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Let's use `st_as_sf()` from `{sf}`

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r}
# spatvector
bolivia_level3 %>% class()

# sf
bolivia_level3 %>% .......() %>% class() #ðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆ
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Useful for `SpatVector` and `SpatialPolygonsDataFrame` objects

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

::: rstudio-cloud
Convert the country borders of Germany from `SpatVector` to a `sf` class object using the `st_as_sf()` function:

```{r,eval=FALSE,echo=TRUE}
gadm(country = "Germany", level = 2, path = tempdir()) %>% 
  ...........
```
:::

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Now with `sf` objects:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r}
ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = geoboundaries(country = "Bolivia")) +
  geom_sf(data = bolivia_level3 %>% 
            
            ........() %>%                 #ðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆ
            
            filter(NAME_1 == "Santa Cruz"),
          mapping = aes(fill = NAME_1))
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

### Vector data {.unnumbered}

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

::: vocab
![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ **Why is the class object called `SpatVector`?**

![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ "SpatVector" stands for *"Spatial Vector"*, and "Vector" stands for **"Vector data"**.

![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ **Vector data** is the formal name for the *Geometry types* like Point, Lines, and Polygons.

![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ It requires a **Coordinate Reference System (CRS)** to relate the spatial elements of the data with the *surface of Earth*.

![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ It is also the **most common format** of Spatial data used in GIS. Which is commonly stored in Shapefiles.
:::

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

::: watch-out
![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ Do not get confused by the `vector` class object,

![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ it is an R class just like `data.frame` and `matrix`.
:::

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Above: how to convert *foreign* **Polygon** data to `sf` class.

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Now: how to convert *foreign* **Point** data to `sf` class!

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

## Disease information with `{malariaAtlas}`

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ `{malariaAtlas}` visualize and manipulate global malaria data

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ hosted by the [Malaria Atlas Project](https://malariaatlas.org/).

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ It downloads data like:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ **parasite** rate (PR) survey data (*Plasmodium falciparum* and *P. vivax*)

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ **mosquito** occurrence data

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

### Parasite Rate surveys {.unnumbered}

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ `getPR()` downloads PR points for a country:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r get-pr,message = FALSE,warning=FALSE}
zimbabwe_malaria_pr <- getPR(country = "Zimbabwe", species = "BOTH")
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ It is of class `dataframe`

```{r}
......(zimbabwe_malaria_pr)
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

::: side-note
The `species` argument is a string specifying the Plasmodium species and can be `Pf` (*Plasmodium falciparum*), `Pv` (*Plasmodium vivax*) or `BOTH`.
:::

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ The `data.frame` contains `longitude` and `latitude` as variables:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r}
zimbabwe_malaria_pr 
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

::: practice
Download the publicly available Parasite Ratio (PR) points for *Plasmodium falciparum* in `Sierra Leone` using the `{malariaAtlas}` package.

```{r,eval = FALSE}
q3 <- ________(________ = "Sierra Leone",species = "Pf")
q3
```

```{r,include = FALSE}
.check_q3()
.hint_q3()
```
:::

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ `autoplot()` can be used...

```{r viz-PR, eval=FALSE, message=FALSE,warning=FALSE}
autoplot(zimbabwe_malaria_pr)
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ However, to make a **custom plot** with complete control of the *aesthetics*,

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ you will prefer `{ggplot2}` for the work!

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

### Convert foreign Point geometries to `sf` {.unnumbered}

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Again, let's use `st_as_sf()` from `{sf}`.

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ But, for **Point** data it requires *two* arguments:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ `coords` - names of the variables holding the **Coordinates**, and

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ `crs` - a **Coordinate Reference System (CRS)** like WGS84 (\#`4326`).

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r,eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE}
zimbabwe_malaria_pr_sf <- 
  
  # data frame
  zimbabwe_malaria_pr %>% 
  
  # convert to sf
  sf::st_as_sf(     )  #ðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆðŸ‘ˆ
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Pay attention to the **`coords` argument**:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ You need `"quotation_marks"` for column names,

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ First `longitude`, then `latitude`.

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ **Mission accomplished!**:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r}
zimbabwe_malaria_pr_sf %>% 
  dplyr::select(site_name,pr)
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Now, let's create a Thematic map!

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Let's plot the `pr` points with a `size` proportional to their value:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r,fig.height=3}
ggplot(data = zimbabwe_malaria_pr_sf) +
  
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ Or add a layer with administrative boundaries of `Zimbabwe`:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r}
zimbabwe_boundaries_adm1 <- geoboundaries(    )
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

â€¢ In the same ggplot:

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

```{r,fig.height=3}
ggplot() +
  
  # boundaries data
  geom_sf(data =      ,
          fill = "white") +
  
  # disease data
  geom_sf(data =      ,
          mapping =      ,
          color = "red",
          alpha=0.5)
```

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

::: watch-out
![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ `sf::st_as_sf()` does not allow **missing** values in coordinates!

![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ So, use `{dplyr}` verbs like `filter()` to drop missing rows

![](images/0-graybox.JPG)

â€¢ for variable `x` use:`filter(!is.na(x))`
:::

![](images/0-whitebox.JPG)

::: practice
With the publicly available Parasite Ratio (PR) points of *Plasmodium falciparum* in Sierra Leone stored in `q3`:

Convert its `data.frame` output to a `sf` object using the `st_as_sf()` function, with the code `4326` to set a `WGS84` CRS. (More on all these codes coming soon, don't be intimidated !)

```{r,eval = FALSE}
q4 <- 
  q3 %>% 
  filter(!is.na(longitude)) %>% 
  sf::________(coords = c("________","________"),
               crs = 4326)
q4
```

```{r, include=FALSE}
.hint_q4()
```
:::
